conclusion: Use Snell's Law and geometric information to find the refractive index.
The glass column has a quarter circle cross section with radius R. Light enters at P on the arc and exits at M on the BC interface. Distance from P to AC is (sqrt(3)R)/2 and MC is (sqrt(3)R)/3.
The angle of incidence θ_i at P is the angle between the radius AP and the horizontal.
Use trigonometry to find θ_i since AP = R and the distance from P to AC is (sqrt(3)R)/2.
The vertical distance from P to AC is (sqrt(3)R)/2 and the horizontal distance from A to the vertical line through P is R/2, forming a 30-60-90 triangle.
The angle θ_r is the angle between the refracted ray and the normal at M.
Snell's Law states n_1 sin θ_i = n_2 sin θ_r.
n_1 = 1 (air) and n_2 is the refractive index of the glass.
Since MC = (sqrt(3)R)/3, the triangle BMC is a 30-60-90 triangle, so θ_r = 60 degrees.
Apply Snell's Law: 1 * sin 30 degrees = n_2 * sin 60 degrees.
sin 30 degrees = 1/2 and sin 60 degrees = sqrt(3)/2.
